subject: Law
title: The Ethics of Plea Bargaining
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Ethics of Plea Bargaining.

hook.text: 97% of federal cases end in plea deals. That means almost no one gets the trial the Constitution promises.

buildup.text: Plea bargaining lets defendants plead guilty to lesser charges in exchange for reduced sentences.

discovery.text: It saves time and resources. Without it, courts would collapse under the weight of trials for every case.

twist.text: Innocent people plead guilty too. Facing decades in prison, a guaranteed short sentence can look like the safer bet.

climax.text: Prosecutors hold enormous power in plea deals. The system gives them leverage that judges and juries don't check.

punchline.text: The right to a trial exists. The system is built to avoid it.

quiz.question: Why do some innocent people accept plea bargains?
options: A guaranteed short sentence seems safer than risking decades
